title: Together, we'll build the BG of 2050.
text:
In the next 25 years, our community will nearly double in size.

What would you want to see in the Bowling Green of the future?

What's a core value we want to preserve/cultivate as we grow?

Share all your dreams between now and October 2nd.

comments.text: Bowling Green will lean into embracing a “post-partisan mindset” and not let national politics define how we solve problems together.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: BG will further embrace its local storytellers—engaging even more with the media from local writers, filmmakers, musicians, & other creators
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will further elevate products made in Kentucky and promote Kentucky products and culture from around the Commonwealth.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will have some places that serve mutton and burgoo.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will embrace considering the I-165 corridor and the Western Kentucky Coalfields area as part of the greater Bowling Green area
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will even further embrace a regional attitude & will become the focal point for promoting attractions/stories of the region
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Locally owned businesses will continue promoting one another and building partnerships across them—and even grow that vibe.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Places to hangout will have the opportunity to invest in sound control so that you don’t have trouble hearing your table mates.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In 2050, Bowling Green will have a host of restaurants/other hangout places that stay open after 9 pm & a robust clientele to support them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In 2050, we will have a robust vision in Bowling Green for 2075.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Strong 2 + 2 degree programs exist between SKYCTC and WKU
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: BG2050 has clearly defined pathways for students from high school to SKYCTC / WKU to high wage / high demand careers
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Local manufacturers should buy in/contribute to campaign to attract workers to fill open positions instead of relying on churn of employees
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In 2050, no one will graduate from WKU and feel that they can’t pursue their career in the region if they want to.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will remain a place where you can move here from anywhere and make a difference.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will be a national model for focusing on the local instead of national culture wars.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will be known nationally for its focus on working to keep key stakeholders aligned and the ease of collaboration here.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green will maintain its spirit of service leadership.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In 2050, Bowling Green will be a distinctive, uniquely Kentucky part of greater Nashville with a distinctive national identity,
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: BG/WC needs to incorporate its rich history and story into its ever burgeoning growth.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In 2050, Bowling Green will be seen throughout the state as Kentucky’s front porch to the south.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: there should be a dedicated left turning lane at Kereiakes Park
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Development of a culture of music. Policies and venues that promote live music and venues.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In 2050, Bowling Green's philosophy will be that the best Government is one that governs least.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: An upscale Outlet would be great!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: An upscale Mall would be great!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Would like to have a Trader Joe's in our community.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Would like to have Whole Foods in our community.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: An upscale Mall and an Outlet would be great!

comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need more daycare facilities.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need a couple of true/real seafood restaurants.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Would like to have Whole Foods and Trader Joe's in our community.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need true bakeries, like those we find in Europe.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Add trolleys that are unique or painted/decorated on different themes.Encourage the use of them to avoid commuting by personal cars downtown
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Would love to have a cultural/ethnic museum with exhibits (rotated or not) from around the world, highlighting the diversity of BG.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The city needs to do everything they can to incentivize affordable housing.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green should leverage its geographic location to act as a bridge for the “north to south”
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Establish a "Wellness Week" each year with free health screenings, fitness classes, and nutrition workshops citywide
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Expand public access to affordable, organic, and locally sourced foods through farmers markets and grocery partnerships.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Create a citywide "Healthy Lifestyle" campaign to promote fitness, nutrition, and mental wellness across all age groups
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Property development can be guided and encouraged by Government but should be accomplished by private land owners.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Develop a floating, fitness-themed river park along the Barren River with paddleboarding, yoga on docks, and riverside trails.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Housing and subdivisions should be separated from industry by buffers like parks or commercial properties.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Establish a “Wellness Hour” where all city offices and businesses encourage a break for light physical activity and mental well-being
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Implement a "Prescription Produce" program where doctors prescribe fresh fruits and vegetables to patients with diet-related conditions.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Convert vacant lots into urban farms, where residents can grow and harvest their own fresh produce.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Establish a citywide "Blue Zones Project" to create environments where residents naturally live healthier, longer lives.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Provide tax incentives for companies that implement employee wellness programs.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Constitutional rights training should be required for all public servants.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Require fitness and nutrition education classes in schools to foster lifelong healthy habits.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The best Government is one that governs least.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Implement incentives for restaurants to offer healthier, locally-grown food options
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Create incentives for restaurants and grocery stores to offer healthier, locally-sourced menu options and produce at affordable prices.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Encourage local businesses to offer employee wellness programs (fitness classes, mental health support, and healthy meal options).
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The city should promote active family days in parks where physical activities, sports, and health education are the focus.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I have never actually seen a cyclist using the bike lanes on the bypass.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green should develop an annual wellness festival celebrating local health experts, fitness programs, and nutrition initiatives.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green should become a leader in preventative medicine and healthy living
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Improve the walking/cycling paths that connect neighborhoods to parks, schools, and downtown for safer, healthier commutes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Establish mandatory nutrition and physical education programs in schools that continue throughout high school for healthier futures.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The city should incentivize small, local fitness businesses
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Create and incentivize a network of wellness coaches in schools and workplaces to guide healthier living and preventative care for all ages.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need more community-supported agriculture (CSA) programs to make fresh, locally-grown food accessible to all families.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green should prioritize building more unique outdoor fitness parks to encourage year-round physical activity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Warren county has some of the most productive agriculture ground in the Commonwealth. I’d like to see some of it left/preserved in 2050.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Have an infrastructure for food rescue, food growing, and food tree planting to direct into food insecure support structures.

comments.text: Bus or larger transit from BG to Nashville and back.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I  would love to see more programs that help those with farms, evolve and continue to prosper.

comments.text: Tax smoke shops and revenue for public parks
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hyperloop or high speed rail on I65 connecting Louisville, Bourbon trail, and Nashville .
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: city needs to enforce 2 hr parking around fountain sq
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Diversify the economy! Need to put as much emphasis on healthcare, tech, creative communities as we do manufacturing.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green to become the 'hub' for all surrounding counties, promoting the entire region, and not just BG/WC.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: restore historic buildings in downtown and not allow them to sit vacant and be a fire hazard
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Beech Bend will become an even larger destination point for visitors, better access to the area should be developed
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: BG of 20250 is a vibrant, art-rich city with its own identity that values, attracts and takes care of people of all ages & perspectives.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In order for Bowling Green to remain easily accessible in the future, additional interchanges to I-65 & I-165 should be developed
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: With 108 birth counties and 90+ languages spoke by new Americans in Warren Co, we need to better embrace and support them as entrepreneurs.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Bowling Green needs a larger convention center attached to an upper scale hotel property in order to attract meetings and conventions
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to focus more attention on recruiting "tech" businesses to Warren Co.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Zoning that includes options for more affordable options like Accessory Dwelling Units and Higher Density.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to encourage and support new hobby farms throughout Warren Co.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to implement affordable "planned communities" designed with 250+ single-family dwellings in and around BG/Warren Co.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need some larger multi-floor condos/apartments in the downtown area increasing foot traffic for "mom&pop" retailers.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to require new downtown building owners to have retailers locate on the first floor facing the street.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to start identifying(naming) "districts" throughout Warren County each with their own style, color(s), etc.

comments.text: We should have creative / interesting tech jobs. Not all manufacturing focused.

comments.text: Enough housing options for all income levels.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More family friendly entertainment options.

comments.text: The Kentucky Museum is a private 501c3, affiliated with WKU but financially self-sufficient & able to be the region's arts and history hub.

comments.text: BG will maintain its unique identity and NOT just be "northern Nashville."

comments.text: The History, Heritage, & "specialness" of Historic Property should be preserved but we shouldn't preserve it for the sake of preserving it.

comments.text: It should be a mix of both. We need new roads in order to open up more land for our growth

comments.text: In 2050, our community continues to support the public library and the work they do to provide access to services and programming for all!

comments.text: Downtown is just one piece of the overall county and we need to focus on ALL parts of BG/WC

comments.text: Let’s start using airport for public events starting with food truck and live musics - open air concert

comments.text: Keep expanding operation pride & incorporate "rewilding" areas of green space w/ native plants and trees which require less maintenance cost

comments.text: Downtown infrastructure will continue to support all major venues activated at once, offering ample parking without any legitimate issues.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Fringe will remain a Downtown food truck park destination concept offering complementary options compared to Downtown restaurants.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Downtown’s parking structure needs exterior projecting signage that shows you can actually park and dine there. You wouldn’t know otherwise.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Shake Rag histories live on thru the Southern Queen Hotel, Mustang Club, Shake Rag Spirits Lounge, & George Washington Carver Center efforts

comments.text: K-12 schools introduce our kids to the heart of our City thru Downtown access to public parks, spaces, events, and venues on field trips.

comments.text: Downtown’s parking structure should hire parking attendants to guide entry and exit, to overall improve the somewhat confusing experience.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More Love BGKY art installations around the community, only built with custom/unique components to that reflect a business, attraction, etc.

comments.text: Lost River Cave should be its Cavern Nite Club once a year with a themed ball. The Cocktails & Trails event is fun, but not quite the same.

comments.text: Historic/nightly walking tours should be encouraged year-round instead of seasonally. Support the hospitality workforce for more tour guides
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Downtown BG needs a couple of boutique hotels, some that tell our unique story. Like the Graduate brand by Hilton that highlights WKU or KY
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More niche cafes, like cat cafes or arcade cafes, will be in our entertainment scene. Ideal for college students and young professionals.

comments.text: The Downtown infrastructure supports all its major venues activated at once without any legitimate parking issues. There is ample parking.

comments.text: Normalize closing major Downtown streets for community-wide events as they grow, I.E. Harvest Fest, Duncan Hines Days, Downtown Lights Up

comments.text: The Fringe is a Downtown food truck park destination and its bookings offer complementary options compared to Downtown restaurants.

comments.text: Trolley/bus loop activates for Downtown events to carry attendees: Fountain Square > Circus Square > Shake Rag > Riverfront > SoKY Market

comments.text: Riverfront’s Whitewater Park will draw river/outdoor recreation enthusiasts/tourists to Downtown. This was a Rivertown once & will be again.

comments.text: Fountain Square will always be the heart of the City. But. It is ok for Downtown to continue growth from the WKU Hill to the Riverfront.
